page.title: 08OLD INDUSTRIES-HOLKER MOSS
page.content: {Roudsea Wood}is named after a Viking chief and there has been woodland on the site for over 1000 years.The main use of the wood has been for{ {coppicing}- the regular cutting of trees and bushes.A lot of coppiced wood was burnt in the vicinity to make {charcoal.}This was then taken by horse drawn railway to the{gunpowder factory at nearby Low Wood.Barrels made from local wood were used to transport the gunpowder to ships which sailed up the estuary.Charcoal was also used to smelt iron.Roudsea provided wood for{ {clog soles}and{bobbins}for the cotton industries of Lancashire.Bark from the trees was used to{tan leather}and{soap was made from the ashes of waste wood which was burnt in pitsteads.Nothing was wasted. Charcoal burners' and tan barkers' huts and pitsteads are visible today.
